Why not use x-ray photons (~15MeV) to unstick the muons from the Helium-3 nuclei? They have enough energy to bring muons up to the dissociation energy for helium (~11MeV), and you get ~150 chances to hit the muon. X-ray pulses every 40 picoseconds would allow the muon to catalyse close to 150 fusion reactions before getting ionised by the x-rays, freeing it from any nucleus it may be stuck to and allowing it to continue catalysing fusion reactions. This can be repeated about 500,000 times until the muon decays, giving about 75 million fusion reactions per muon, or 1.3PeV output per muon. Assuming 99.9% of x-rays fail to ionise the muon, this is still 1.3TeV output per 5GeV input to produce a muon. I'm sure my numbers aren't perfect and I'm probably missing something, but this feels like a step forward? Especially if particle accelerators get more efficient to reduce the energy required to produce muons in the first place.

What if I accelerated say, a nitrogen nucleus at a solid hydrogen target across a voltage drop, say in an inertial electrostatic confinement scheme. When the nitrogen nucleus hits a hydrogen, the impact produces 2 pions, which decay into a negative and positive muon. The positive muon strips an electron from the hydrogen, and the negative muon "sticks" to the nitrogen. The nitrogen, with a single muon in the 1s1 subshell, enters into a weird bond with the hydrogen, and the two fuse via muon catalysis, yielding a high energy helium nucleus which spits out of the solid target, and a carbon nucleus with a stuck muon. Because the confinement sceme is electrostatic, the 11+ charged muonic carbon goes on to capture another proton, to be become carbon 13,then another, to become nitrogen 14, then another, to become oxygen 15, which decays to regenerate the initial nitrogen catalyst (the CNO cycle). This elimates the sticking problem, as the muon will stick to the heavier CNO catalyst, and the generation problem, as the reaction is aneutronic and power could be directly generated from the momentum of the alpha particles across the electrostatic field. Would it be possible to generate the muons needed directly at the surface of the fusion target from a focused beam of CNO catalyst? Accelerate the catalyst rather than the fuel?

Cold fusion easy. Neutrons have a negative charge
when you get really close. A helium 3 molecule near
absolute 0 becomes magnetized and solid under a high
magnetic field. As the molecules are lined up, you
have 2 protons orbiting a neutron. As they approach
each other from rapid compression, they will offset
so the neutrons line up vs the other's protons. This
will greatly reduce the coulomb barrier. The
neutrons get hit by 1 of the orbit protons of the
other. They twist into a Helium 4 nucleus and the
other 2 protons fly off at high speed in opposite
directions. No photons or neutrons emitted. Just pure
kinetic energy in charged particles. Many ways to
soak that up.

One small wrinkle with any potential 80's style cold fusion; it can't stay cold. You can initiate the reaction at very low temperature, but since physics prohibits perfectly efficient systems, you can't capture all of the energy from the fusion reaction, and the reactor gets very hot, very fast. It wouldn't be millions of degrees, but it's not going to be anything remotely 'cold' either.

The real question is, can the Muon throw that 105.7M eV of mass-energy into the 1.29 MeV needed to turn a proton into a neutron, without the pure compressive forces being high enough to allow that. Great explanation in a short capsule. The problem in the production of negative muons is that you'll get positive, neutral and negative pions from the proton collisions, and the lesser fraction will be negative pions, which are the ones decaying into negative muons. In other words, much of the energy is lost in the production of useless pions. Maybe if high energy physicists could figure out the way of fixing this, the problem could be solved. By the way, around 1985 or 86 there was a brief revival of muon catalised fusion research, when it was proven by  Rafelski and Jones (yes, the same physicists who claimed they had obtained "cold fusion", independently from chemists Fleischmann and Pons) that the number of fusions per muon could be increased under certain conditions. There was even a specialised journal on the subject, but it faded within a few years.

The only reason the Sun DOES indeed perform fusion is because of quantum tunelling, fusion events within the Sun's core are actualyl extremely rare, it just so happens that the Sun's core is so massive and there is so much plasma that even at that low low rate, we still get a lot of fusion going to sustain a slow burn of the Sun.

If the Sub DID have the thermodynamics to sustain fusion (which would mean more than 30 million K), it would burn out much faster, the hottest stars burn out the fasters because of this.


On earth we can actually sustain fusion @ 150.000.000 K and just 2 atm, which is actually a better deal (turns out T is a much more influential parameter than P in fusion) except we can't do it for long enough for tehnical reasons, we also have a bad time at using that energy.

But the point is, humans actually are BETTER at performing fusion than the Sun is (thermodynamically), the Sun just makes up for this by having way more plasma to use than we do.
